reviewText: The beginning of the movie was shot in and around my grandfather's home.  It was nice to see how the filmaker portrayed the house.  I could see many parts of the house that had stayed the same.  When the young girl left her home after her mother abandoned her, the storyline went down hill from there.  There are sexual and abusive parts in the film that were mishandled.  The only good part of the film was when the young girl used art to tell her story.

reviewText: I decided to watch this for two reasons.  1.  All of the critics panned it, and so I wanted to see if it was bad as everyone thought.  2.  Chloe Moretz is in it, she is a very good young actress, and so I believed that she might save this flick, no matter how bad it might be.But unfortunately, this is surely not one of Ms. Moretz's best performances.  Usually she gives it all she's got; watch "Kick A--" where she is Hit Girl if you disagree with me.  Or "Let Me In" as well, where she was terrific.  (I actually liked her performance in that better than the original performance in the foreign film "Let the Right One In.")  But here, even she seems to almost mail it in.  I'm not convinced that she was into this during filming herself, and so I believe that she just went through the motions.  (My apologies to this fine young actress in advance if I am mistaken.)When I watch a film, I always try to figure out what the theme is as soon as possible.  Here, I struggled, thinking, "What is the theme?  Is it, 'You're born, life stinks, and then you die'?"  But then I took a peek at the virtual DVD cover from the streaming version, and it says something like, "Trouble Travels Together."  Is this a hint, and if so, are they saying, "Troubled people hook up with other troubled people" - kind of a take on "Birds of a feather. . ." - or is it, "For some people trouble just seems to follow."  I also considered, "Everyone creates his own little fantasy world just to get through the day."  But the sad thing is, whatever the main theme happens to be, I don't much care anyway since the movie was just kind of blah.There is one major issue with this film.  Since it was filmed in the US, and due to the age of the main character - Ms. Moretz - there were certain scenes that could not be shown that were therefore simply implied.  I still wonder what happened in those scenes since the action wasn't shown.  But I believe that this watered down the original story perhaps.  I believe that it was adapted from a book, and it would be interesting to read that book to confirm my suspicions.Now, the director seems to be potentially a fan of David Lynch.  There are a couple of scenes - and musical choices - that tips this off.  Not to give too much away, but there is a shooting scene that reminded me of the movie "Blue Velvet."  And there is a close-up camera shot on the burner on a stove that seemed "Lynchian" as well.  I used to be a big fan of Mr. Lynch, but I have to admit, I started getting tired of his films as he seems to recycle some of these elements over and over and over.  But before you get too excited, I'd still recommend the controversial "Blue Velvet" for a very entertaining watch.  It's still one of my favorites due to it's quirkiness.But as for "Hick"?  Can I recommend it?  Well, probably not.  I don't believe that it is as bad as the critics think, but it is close enough.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I went into this movie thinking it was going to be total garbage, based on the reviews by critics. Wow, was I surprised. Did the critics see the same film I saw? Not only is this film not garbage, but I really liked it! The acting is very good, especially the scene stealing Eddie Redmayne. Chloe was born to play Luli and Blake Lively even shows some acting chops as Glenda. Don't get me wrong, this is not a perfect film, it has it's pacing and plot hole problems and had I not read the book, I might even have been lost in a spot or two. It's definitely not a film for everyone based on the dark subject matter, but if you're looking for something good that is away from the mainstream dreck that Hollywood pumps out on a daily basis, then check this one out. This film is based on the excellent book by Andrea Portes and she even pens the screenplay. A pretty decent job for a first-time screenwriter. I suggest reading the book before seeing the movie. My only gripe is that I wish this DVD wasn't so bare bones. Hopefully there is a director's cut coming and how about a Blu-Ray???
summary: The critics ripped it, but I thought it was pretty good!

reviewText: Luli (Chloe Grace Moretz) can't take her mom's drinking and Nebraska boredom, so she runs away, heading for Las Vegas. Hitching a ride from Eddie (Eddie Redmayne), she soon learns he's Big Trouble. Kind-hearted Glenda (Blake Lively) gives the teen a ride, which puts Luli back in trouble when they encounter Eddie a second time. Redmayne does a good job portraying a jerk we love to hate--complete with Luli's kidnapping and bondage. Fortunately for Luli, campsite owner Beau (Alec Baldwin) takes an interest in the situation. Chloe Grace Moretz delivers yet another strong performance, adding some lipstick to this ugly one.
summary: Home Wasn't So Bad In Hindsight.

reviewText: Yeah, I'd seen her play Hit Girl, and knew she was a talent to watch.  But her performance in this is nothing short of phenomenal.This movie deserves much more praise than it has received; I'm not sure why it never got recognized.  Perhaps it is just too depressing for most audiences-- it's downright heartbreaking actually.If you can handle the bleak storyline, do check it out.  All of the acting is excellent, but this is Chloe Moretz's film all the way.  Here's hoping she, at least, will one day get the recognition she deserves.  She is one of the best actors out there, of any age.
summary: Chloe Moretz Deserved The Oscar For This

reviewText: They picked a terrific actress to play a drifting womanish child, but a terrible actor for the nerdy outlaw.  The story fancies itself "Nebraska gothic" but never delivers much interest externally or internally.  The characters simply are never given much to say or do.  It needed a great script doctor to throw in some symbolic details.

reviewText: I admit to being a big fan of Chloe Moretz-I think she is the finest young actress out there now,so I will check out all her work as she moves along in her career. On the weekend Dark Shadows was released,I was suprised to see this little film she was in had come out(I had heard nothing about it),and was curious to see it.I was shocked at how every "pro critic" panned it on a level I have almost never seen. If you only look at those reviews,you might think it is the worst film ever made. I still wanted to see it,but it didn't come out anywhere that I could. In fact,on the week it was released on DVD,it wasn't even available on the cable system "on demand". The worst films made get treated better.So the DVD shows up,and a friend and I(who also is a fan of hers)sit down to watch it. I warn her about the horrid reviews,and we were all set to see a very bad movie.Were these paid critics watching the same film as I saw? It was dark,and often very intense. But it was a really good movie,with outstanding acting,a well done script,and well done in terms of filming and editing. There were no scenes of anything over the top shown on screen. If you are into watching things that explore the kind of subjects involved in this film,you should be sure and give it a chance.To the "pro critics" who tried to destroy this film-maybe they need a new job,because they do not know anything about movies. This is a solid effort that can make you sad,make you feel,make you think,and once in awhile,make you have to chuckle a bit. It's worth giving it a chance to see what you think,and not what you were told to think.I will buy it again if it is made available on blue-ray.

reviewText: We have all seen movies about teens who yearn for a more glamorous life and run away to try and find that life. So there is nothing really new about the overall plot and a lot of it is a bit cliche. But what makes this movie go is Chloe Moretz. She delivers what should be an Oscar worthy performance. She goes from innocent to precocious to sensual. Just like Brooke Shields had Pretty Baby and Dakota Fanning had Hound Dog, this is the movie that takes a popular young actress and puts her in situations that are sexually charged, dangerous, and yes....just plain hot.Of course Chloe  will probably not be nominated because of her age, the weakness of the overall plot, and because the PC crowd would find this movie "exploitive of a minor" or some such rubbish.This movie is really about Chloe and her expansion into more mature roles that allow her in-born sensuality and sex-appeal to come forward. And the movie plays to these strengths. Make no mistake, Chloe has the same appeal to men as other "hot" female film stars in spite of her age. But she is not just some eye-candy girl, she is a first rate actress who is wise beyond her years. And the way she attracts legions of male admirers is undeniable. Obviously, Hollywood has noticed this and cast her accordingly. If you are one of her admirers, this movie is a must have.Four stars only because the plot is a bit "tired".
Title: N/A

reviewText: Plot implausibility and exaggerated villains aside, you still have a four star, little-film gem.  The natural and unforced acting of Chloe Moretz is the single best aspect of "Hick" and makes it entertaining without getting bogged down in plot contrivance and predictability.  Pacing is even handed, and although the film is alternately violent and sweet it never overdoes either aspect.  The most memorable aspects of "Hick" are those in which Chloe's character becomes introspective and thoughtful about her life arc.  The weakest points when director Derick Martini succumbs to the nearly fatal flaw of exaggerating antagonists to the point of parody.  The soundtrack is spot-on and appropriately low key.One big misstep is the casting of Juliette Lewis, playing the 43rd redneck whore lowlife in her illustrious career.  I almost stopped watching 15 minutes in.  I'm very glad I didn't.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a fantastic movie and I know know why this didn't get more fanfare or screens in the theater.  This is a "coming of age" story, but a very gritty one.  Luli just wants to be accepted and to find her place in the world. To put it simply, she just wants to belong. She knows that if she can just make it to Las Vegas, things will be fine, and she will find her spot in life. Along the way, she meets people and some of them aren't as trust worthy as she thinks they are.  Luli tries to hang on to her innocents through her drawings, they're a source of  inspiration for her. As the saying goes, "every picture tells a story" and we get to see a different side of Luli. That's all I really want to say about the plot.Chloe Moretz gives another fine performance, actually, it's superb.  I love how Chloe portrayed Luli's innocents, and child like wonder through her drawings, yet is living in an adult world.  This movie really shows Chloe's actability and range. It's no wonder she's a talented actress. If you're a fan of hers, then you have to see this movie!I'm not so sure why this has a few low ratings, but trust me, this is worth it.  I just can't figure out why this isn't on blu ray.This is a coming of age movie, but it's gritty.  If you see it, I can promise you won't be sorry, I know  I wasn't.

reviewText: Like people have said this is actually a very good movie, it maybe not everyone's cup of tea though as it is very slow paced and takes time to develop the thin plot running through it, its more of a strong character based movie, the day in the life of a young girl who runs away from home to go to Vegas and find a more exciting life where she can maybe be somebody or even be loved by somebody but she unfortunately runs into the wrong people and she is just led down a road of drugs and violence, it's a very well acted movie if you can stick with it, Chloe Moretz is very beautiful and an extremely convincing actress and she certainly keeps the movie going as the centre star, it's worth checking out if your into a quieter and less action more story type of movie.

reviewText: "You could shake your knuckles at the sky, you could get mad and say I don't got nothing', you could get stuck." Thirteen year old Luli (Moretz) comes from a very messed up family. She spends the night of her 13th birthday at a bar with her parents and when the dad is too drunk to drive home a big fight occurs. When her mother leaves with an insurance man and her dad gets mad and leaves she is left alone. Deciding she needs a fresh start she heads out on her own for Las Vegas. The best way to describe this movie really is to compare it to the movie "Jolene" that came out a few years ago. But I'm guessing most people didn't see it so I will do my best. It sounds strange to say this but this is a coming of age story about a 13 year old girl. Through the people she meets on her way she has new life experiences that involves things she shouldn't learn about for at least 5 more years. Moretz is amazing in this and I just wonder how long it will take until she wins an Oscar. The cast in this is also very good and the movie is very much worth watching all the way to the surprising and bittersweet ending. I liked it. Overall, a very good movie about a not so typical life of a 13 year old. I give it a B.
summary: A different kind of coming of age story. Great acting and depressing story. If you liked "Jolene" watch this one. I say B.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Chlo Grace Moretz, best known as "Hit-Girl" of "Kick-Ass," stars in "Hick," a coming-of-age drama about a 13-year-old girl Luli McMullen, who runs away from her Nebraska home with a sketchbook and a Smith and Wesson in her handbag. On the way she encounters a former rodeo cowboy Eddie Kreezer (Eddie Redmayne) and a cocaine-snorting swindler Glenda (Blake Lively)."Hick" has almost everything that we would want in this kind of film: gifted actors and nice soundtrack music, plus excellent photography that captures the landscapes. What it doesn't have is a decent script. The story of Luli unfolds in a rather slow manner, but it was alright with me. Watching some of the events that happen to the girl is not very comfortable (though discreetly handled), but, sure, these things could happen in real life.But ... what is the point of the movie? "Hick" starts out as a film about Luli's growing pains, but halfway through the film Eddie (and to a lesser degree Glenda) takes over the story. They may not be very likable, but at least they are more interesting than the heroine Luli about whom we don't know much about. She tells much about her young brother in her voiceovers, but not much about herself. There are certainly fairy-tale undercurrents in the film (Luli is often seen mimicking characters from classic movies), but that part of the film is not fully explored.One good thing about "Hick" is the performances from the cast (including underused Alec Baldwin). Most memorable among them is Eddie Redmayne, who is to be seen in Tom Hooper-directed musical "Les Misérables." His portrayal of the unpredictable and quick-tempered Eddie is often fascinating in a disturbing way in this uneven drama.
Title: N/A
